EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.01
	 
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Receive First Reading of Proposed Amended Board Bylaw #9270 Conflict of Interest Code: Revolving Door Policy and #9270E (Appendix A) Designated Positions/Disclosure Categories
	 
	 
	 
Pursuant to the Government Code, the District is required to adopt a conflict of interest code. The District's conflict of interest code is contained in Board Bylaw 9270. The Government Code and the Rules and Regulations adopted by the Fair Political Practices Commission require the District to designate positions which are required to submit disclosures of financial interests, and to update the titles of positions when new positions are created, when position titles are changed, or when positions or position duties are revised or modified to fall within the disclosure categories. The changes reflected in the attached draft proposed revised Board Bylaw 9270 and 9270E (Appendix A) reflect revisions requested by County Counsel and also include the positions of Director III, Director of Special Services, District Architect, Project Manager and Senior Manager of Internal Controls within the category of positions required to submit disclosures, and delete the Interim Superintendent of Schools position. 
. 
	 
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board receive this first reading of the proposed amendment to Board Bylaw 9270 and 9270E (Appendix A) thereto as presented.

SUBJECT:
Receive and Adopt Second Reading of Proposed New, Amended and Deleted Facilities Use Related Board Policies and Administrative Regulations
	 
	 
	 
In order to comply with State and Federal regulations, it is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive and review the second reading of the attached facilities use related Board Policies and Administrative Regulations that have been recommended by CSBA and modified to meet the needs of East Side Union High School District. Also included for second reading are recommended Board Polices for deletion by the Board. 
	 
The following Board Policies and Administrative Regulations are presented to the Board  for for second reading and adoption:
	 
BP 1330 Use of School Facilities
AR 1330 Use of School Facilities
BP 1330.1 Joint Use Agreements
AR 1330.2 Rules and Regulations for the Use of Facilities for Non-School Purposes
AR 1330.2 (Exhibit) Rules and Regulations for the Use of Facilities for Non-School Purposes
BP 1330.3 Use of Swim Facilities
BP 1330.5 Policy on Use of Swim Facilities
	 
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
âIt is recommended that the Board receive and adopt the second reading of the proposed new, amended, and deleted facilities use related Board Policies and Administrative Regulations, specifically Board Policy 1330 Use of School Facilities; Administrative Regulation 1330 Use of School Facilities; Board Policy 1330.1 Joint Use Agreements; Administrative Regulation 1330.2 Rules and Regulations for the Use of Facilities for Non-School Purposes; Administrative Regulation 1330.2 (Exhibit) Rules and Regulations for the Use of Facilities for Non-School Purposes; Board Policy  1330.3 Use of Swim Facilities; and, Board Policy 1330.5 Policy on Use of Swim Facilities.

PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Early Alert Program: Update on School Efforts to Increase Use of School Loop
	 
The use of School Loop helps students and parents monitor their progress in their classes.  Parents can keep track of upcoming assignments and exams and see how their child is performing in class.  It provides parents vital information to intervene as soon as they see a downward trend in their child's performance and a quick way to communicate with the teachers.  All schools have put measures in place to increase the use of School Loop by teachers, students, and parents.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  12.04
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services, and Robert Ibarra, Coordinator of Professional Development/Migrant Education
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Receive the Third Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaints Quarterly Report for Period Covering July 1, 2012 through September 30, 2012 as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727)
	 
BACKGROUND
As a result of the Williams Case (EC 35186), referred to as a landmark Superior Court case requires that every California public school provide each student with, at the very least, sufficient textbooks and instructional materials; clean, safe and functional buildings and facilities; and permanent, appropriately trained and assigned teachers.  Additionally, under the settlement of the Valenzuela / CAHSEE Settlement (EC 37254) students in grades 10 to 12 inclusive shall be notified of services available to students up to two consecutive years after the completion of grade 12, who have not yet passed the CAHSEE.
	 
School districts shall support summarized data on the nature and resolution of all Williams Complaints and Valenzuela / CAHSEE Complaints on a quarterly basis to the governing board and the county superintendent of schools.  The report shall include the number of complaints by general subject area with the number of resolved and unresolved complaints.
	 
The attached report indicates the number of complaints filed from July 1, 2012 through September 30, 2012. 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
Other Categorical Funds as Appropriate
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the Third Quarterly Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint report for the period covering July 1, 2012 through September 30, 2012, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  14.03
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:  
					 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Rogelio Ruiz, Legal Counsel, Rehon & Roberts, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Approve Proposed Termination of Professional Services Agreement and Purchase Orders Between East Side Union High School District and Bruce Flyn & Associates, Inc.
	 
The Governing Board previously awarded contracts to Bruce Flyn & Associates, Inc. (“BFAI”) to provide State-mandated inspection services on the District’s Measure E projects.  Most recently, the District entered into contracts with BFAI (see Purchase Order nos. 000208 and 103211) whereby BFAI is providing inspector-of-record services on the District’s James Lick High School New Two-Story Building 500 Project, the Mt. Pleasant High School New Classroom Modernization Project and the Silver Creek High School Multi-Purpose Classroom Project (the “BFAI Contracts”).  
	 
The contracts for those projects each provides that BFAI shall defend, indemnify and hold the District harmless from and against, among other things, any and all claims, loss, cost, damage, injury, expense and liability that arise from or relate to BFAI’s negligent performance of the inspection services, any negligent act or omission of BFAI or its sub consultant(s), and any breach of the respective BFAI Contracts.
	 
BFAI has also provided extensive inspection services to the District in the past in connection with previous Measure E and Measure G projects and other Capital Facilities (non-bond) projects.  At this time and for various reasons, forty-five (45) of those projects are lacking final DSA closeout certification (the “uncertified projects”).
	 
BFAI has requested that the District agree to terminate the BFAI contracts due to unforeseen personal circumstances relating to the principal of BFAI.  After consultation with Legal Counsel, Administration is willing to recommend termination provided the termination does not impair the District’s indemnity rights and protections under the BFAI contracts, that the termination does not result in any substantial added expense to the District, the termination does not unduly delay any of the projects, and provided the District receives BFAI’s written assurances that BFAI will cooperate with and assist the District in submitting final documentation required from BFAI necessary for final certification for each of the uncertified projects.
	 
	 
Legal Counsel has prepared the attached Termination of Professional Services Agreement which includes each of the above stipulations and protections in favor of the District.  If the Board approves the proposed agreement and termination, Administration has recommended that the inspection services on each of the above projects be awarded to Furman & Associates, Inc. (James Lick High School New Two-Story Building 500 Project), Santa Clara Valley Construction Inspections (SCVCI),  (Mt. Pleasant High School New Classroom Modernization Project), and Santa Clara Valley Construction Inspections (SCVCI),  (Silver Creek High School Multi-Purpose Classroom Project), which actions have been agendized under Item 16.10 for the Board’s separate consideration, discussion and action.  As detailed in that agenda item, each of those inspectors has been actively engaged as an inspector on their respective project identified above since the inception of each project as a District-approved inspector on the project in affiliation with BFAI.  The direct retention of their services by the District will avoid/minimize any disruption to those projects and minimize and/or avoid any additional costs.
	 
Agreement forthcoming.
	 
	 
Funding Source:
Measure G and Measure E, as applicable
	 
Fiscal Impact:
To be determined
	 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the proposed Termination of Professional Services Agreement and Purchase Orders between the District and Bruce Flyn & Associates, Inc. as presented.

SUBJECT:

Attached is a list of warrants issued during the month of September 2012, in response to Board Policy 3314 Payment for Goods and Services adopted by the Board in May 2009.  The Policy states that, “The Board shall approve all warrants (checks) at a regularly scheduled Board meeting".  While there is no legal requirement for Board approval of issued warrants, this list and future lists will add to the “transparency” of when the Board approves purchase orders, contracts and other authorized expenses as per Board Policies.

SUBJECT:
Receive Accel Program Report
	 
Accel Middle College at Evergreen Valley College is a cooperative program between ESUHSD and San Jose Evergreen Valley Community College.  Accel juniors and seniors are concurrently enrolled in college courses during the morning and high school classes in the afternoon.  Students receive both high school education while experiencing college coursework.  All classes, including high school courses, are held on the Evergreen Valley College campus.
